awd_abstract_narration:
The turbulent movement of air is important for the transport of heat, momentum and moisture throughout the atmosphere.  Turbulence is generally thought of as a small-scale phenomenon, and the generation and dissipation of turbulence has been assumed to be within one grid cell of a numerical weather model.  However, with computer models running at finer resolution, it is not clear that this assumption is valid.  This award will make use of a catalog of observations of wind and turbulence from lidar (Light Detection and Ranging) systems to study turbulence dissipation.  The study will have an impact on weather forecasting, with specific applications to wind power production, air quality forecasting, fog, and forest fires.  As a CAREER award, there is also a very large educational and outreach component.  The focus of this aspect of the award is on creating teaching materials that are visually appealing and can be used from the middle school ages on up.  The research team will help to create a lesson plan and to work with teachers to ensure use of the materials.  A specific focus will be on the implementation of the materials in rural, under-served Colorado classrooms.

Turbulence production and dissipation is assumed to be locally balanced in numerical models.  However, as the models are run at finer resolution, this assumption no longer holds.  The goal of this research project is to determine at what spatio-temporal scale the local imbalance between turbulence production and dissipation becomes important.  Four research activities are planned to address this goal:  (1) Quantify uncertainty in lidar estimates of dissipation, (2) Quantify the variability of dissipation through the construction of a data archive consisting of measurements classified by different meteorological and physical conditions, (3) Compare simulated dissipation variability to observations using WRF and WRF-LES modeling systems, (4) Test new parameterizations that do not assume locally balanced turbulence production and dissipation.

por.por_cntn:
Simulations of the wind over the surface of the earth are needed for transportation, agriculture, air quality, and wind energy forecasts. A major stumbling block in simulating the wind is how turbulence is represented in models. The focus of this project was to try to better understand the balance between the creation and destruction of turbulence in several different regions and circumstances.  Capitalizing on recent developments in measurements, namely wind lidar, this project developed new ways of estimating the destruction of turbulence, or “turbulence dissipation rate.” Using data collected in numerous field campaigns in flat terrain, hilly and complex terrain, mountainous regions, and offshore, this project provided new insights into how dissipation rate varies with daily and seasonal cycles, and how variations in terrain affect turbulence generation and decay. These unique measurements showed that the current approaches to simulating the balance between the production and destruction of turbulence are not adequate. The assumption of balance is not appropriate when using simulation tools with grids of 2 km or finer. New simulation approaches that avoid the restriction of local balance between production and dissipation of turbulence are required. Initial testing of one of these approaches, a 3D PBL scheme, shows promise when compared to observations.

Intellectual merit: The proposed effort developed and expanded novel measurement techniques to quantify the variability of turbulence dissipation rate. First steps compared the novel lidar-based approaches to established tower-based approaches in both flat and hilly terrain. Once confidence in the new approach was established, the novel approach was applied to several datasets in a variety of circumstances. Specific research outputs include: (i) measurement of turbulence dissipation rate over diurnal and seasonal cycles in flat terrain, hilly terrain, mountainous terrain, and offshore, (ii) demonstration of the inadequacy of current modeling approaches to capture variability of turbulence dissipation rate, (iii) testing of machine learning approaches for predicting dissipation rate, and (iv) testing of new simulation approaches offshore and in complex terrain. Initial testing suggests that a 3D PBL scheme reduces some errors in predictions of turbulence.

Broader impacts: The new modeling approaches may improve our ability to simulate flow in complex terrain and heterogeneous terrain, therefore, improving the accuracy and fidelity of numerical weather prediction models. These more accurate predictions will support critical applications such as air quality, aviation, wind energy, transportation, and climate modeling. Furthermore, this grant contributed to the high-quality training of several graduate and undergraduate student researchers, many of which are from underrepresented groups. The project has also created numerous educational tools for K-12, undergraduate, and graduate education. These tools include videos on the basics of wind and how wind turbines harvest the wind, data puzzles and accompanying curricula for middle and high school science teachers, and multiple teacher workshops presented at national science teacher meetings to support the use of these materials in K-12 science classrooms.
